expanded_description: How does money flow through an economy? Where does it come from, where does it go, and how do households, firms, and governments interact? The circular flow model answers these questions by providing a visual representation of economic activity. Imagine money as blood circulating through the economic body—households earn income by providing labor to firms, then use that income to buy goods and services from firms, which gives firms revenue to pay households, and the cycle continues. This simple but powerful model helps us understand how different sectors are interconnected, how GDP is measured, and how government policy affects the economy. It shows that one person's spending is another person's income—a fundamental insight that explains why recessions can spiral and why stimulus can multiply through the economy. In this section, we'll start with the simplest two-sector model and gradually add government, financial markets, and the international sector. You'll learn to trace the flows of money, resources, and goods, and understand why the circular flow is the foundation for measuring national income and output.

core_concept.principle: The circular flow model is a simplified representation of how money, resources, and goods flow between different sectors of the economy. The basic model includes households (who own resources and consume goods) and firms (who produce goods and hire resources). Households supply factors of production—labor, land, capital, entrepreneurship—to firms through factor markets. In return, they receive income—wages, rent, interest, profit. Households use this income to buy goods and services from firms through product markets. This creates a continuous circular flow: money flows from households to firms (spending) and back to households (income). The model can be expanded to include government (collecting taxes and providing services), financial markets (channeling savings into investment), and the international sector (exports and imports). The circular flow illustrates key macroeconomic concepts: that total spending equals total income, that leakages (savings, taxes, imports) must equal injections (investment, government spending, exports) for the economy to be in equilibrium, and that disruptions in any part of the flow can affect the entire economy.
core_concept.explanation: Imagine a simple economy with only households and firms. Households own all the resources—their labor, any land they have, any capital they've accumulated. Firms need these resources to produce goods. So households sell their resources to firms in factor markets. A worker sells labor, receives a wage. A landlord rents out land, receives rent. An investor provides capital, receives interest. An entrepreneur starts a business, receives profit. All this income flows to households. Now households have money, and they want goods and services. So they go to product markets and buy what firms have produced. This spending becomes revenue for firms, which they use to pay for more resources, and the cycle continues. That's the basic circular flow—money goes around and around. Now add government: it collects taxes from households and firms (a leakage from the flow) and spends money on roads, schools, defense (an injection back into the flow). Add financial markets: households save some income (leakage), and firms borrow those savings to invest in new capital (injection). Add international trade: imports send money abroad (leakage), exports bring money in (injection). For the economy to be stable, total leakages must equal total injections. If they don't, the economy expands or contracts. This model helps us understand everything from recessions to fiscal policy.

sections.introduction: The circular flow model is the foundation of macroeconomic analysis. It shows how the different parts of an economy fit together and how money, resources, and goods move between them. Understanding this model is essential for grasping how GDP is measured, how fiscal and monetary policy work, and why economies experience booms and recessions. We'll start with the simplest two-sector model and build up to the full five-sector model that includes households, firms, government, financial markets, and the international sector. By tracing the flows, you'll see why total spending equals total income, why leakages must equal injections for equilibrium, and how government policy can influence economic activity.

introduction_image.alt: Preview diagram showing the full circular flow with all five sectors
introduction_image.caption: Figure 2.1.2: The complete circular flow model includes households, firms, government, financial markets, and the international sector.

key_concept.definition: The circular flow model traces the movement of money, resources, and goods between different sectors of the economy. The basic two-sector model includes households (resource owners and consumers) and firms (producers). Money flows from households to firms as payment for goods and services (consumption spending). Money flows from firms to households as payment for resources (wages, rent, interest, profit). This creates a continuous loop. The expanded model adds: (1) Government—collects taxes (leakage) and spends on goods, services, and transfers (injection); (2) Financial markets—channel household savings (leakage) into business investment (injection); (3) International sector—imports (leakage) send money abroad, exports (injection) bring money in. For equilibrium, total leakages (savings + taxes + imports) must equal total injections (investment + government spending + exports). The circular flow illustrates that total spending equals total income equals total output—the foundation of national income accounting.
key_concept.context: The circular flow model has its roots in the work of French economist François Quesnay in the 18th century, who developed the 'Tableau Économique' to show how wealth flowed between classes in the economy. Modern versions build on the insights of John Maynard Keynes and others who emphasized the importance of aggregate demand and the interdependence of economic sectors. In AP Macroeconomics, the circular flow is used to introduce national income accounting, showing why GDP can be measured as spending, income, or output. It also provides the framework for understanding the multiplier effect—how an initial injection of spending ripples through the economy. The model's emphasis on leakages and injections is central to analyzing fiscal and monetary policy. Understanding the circular flow helps you see the economy as an interconnected system, not just a collection of individual markets.

image.alt: Detailed circular flow diagram with all five sectors and labeled flows
image.caption: Figure 2.1.3: The five-sector circular flow model showing all major flows between households, firms, government, financial markets, and the international sector.

classifications.behavior: Households supply resources to firms in factor markets, receiving income. They spend all income on goods and services in product markets. Firms use revenue to pay for resources. The flow is perfectly circular with no leakages or injections. This model illustrates the fundamental identity: total spending = total income = total output.

image.alt: Circular flow diagram with only households and firms, factor markets and product markets
image.caption: Figure 2.1.4: Two-sector circular flow. All household income is spent; all firm revenue returns to households.

examples.explanation: Resources (labor, land, capital) flow from households to firms through factor markets. Goods and services flow from firms to households through product markets. This is the physical side of the economy.
Income (wages, rent, interest, profit) flows from firms to households through factor markets. Spending flows from households to firms through product markets. This is the financial side.

In this simple model, the value of output produced by firms exactly equals the income earned by households, which exactly equals the spending by households. This identity ($Y = C$) is the foundation of national income accounting.

characteristics: Government spends on goods and services
classifications.behavior: Government enters the flow by collecting taxes from households and firms (a leakage from the circular flow) and by spending on goods and services and making transfer payments (an injection). When government spending exceeds taxes, there's a budget deficit, which adds a net injection to the flow. When taxes exceed spending, there's a surplus, a net leakage.

image.alt: Circular flow diagram with households, firms, and government showing tax flows and government spending
image.caption: Figure 2.1.5: Three-sector model adds government. Taxes (T) are a leakage; government spending (G) is an injection.

examples.explanation: When households pay taxes, that money leaves the circular flow—it's not available to buy consumer goods. This reduces aggregate demand unless the government injects it back through spending.
When government buys goods from firms or pays salaries to government employees, it injects money back into the circular flow, increasing aggregate demand.

Transfer payments (like Social Security or unemployment benefits) are government payments to households without any current goods or services in return. These are injections that increase household income and spending.

classifications.value: Households, firms, government, and financial markets
classifications.behavior: Households do not spend all income—some is saved. Savings flow into financial markets (banks, stocks, bonds) and are a leakage from the circular flow. Firms borrow these savings to finance investment in capital goods (machinery, factories). Investment is an injection. For equilibrium, savings must equal investment ($S = I$) in this simplified model.

image.alt: Circular flow diagram adding financial markets between savings and investment
image.caption: Figure 2.1.6: Four-sector model adds financial markets. Savings (S) are a leakage; investment (I) is an injection.

examples.explanation: When households save, they don't spend that money on current consumption. This reduces aggregate demand unless the savings are borrowed and spent by someone else—firms investing.
When firms borrow from financial markets to buy new equipment or build new factories, they inject spending into the economy. This spending creates income for workers and suppliers.

The market where savers supply funds and borrowers demand funds. The interest rate adjusts to balance supply and demand. This market connects the saving decisions of households with the investment decisions of firms.

classifications.value: Households, firms, government, financial markets, and international sector
classifications.behavior: The international sector adds two flows: exports (domestic goods sold abroad) and imports (foreign goods bought domestically). Exports bring money into the economy (injection). Imports send money abroad (leakage). Net exports ($NX = X - M$) can be positive (trade surplus), negative (trade deficit), or zero. In the full model, equilibrium requires total leakages equal total injections: $S + T + M = I + G + X$.

image.alt: Complete circular flow diagram with all five sectors and all flows labeled
image.caption: Figure 2.1.7: The complete five-sector circular flow. All leakages (S, T, M) and injections (I, G, X) are shown.

examples.explanation: When households buy imported goods, the money leaves the domestic economy. It doesn't become income for domestic firms or workers. This reduces domestic aggregate demand.
When foreign buyers purchase domestic goods, money flows into the economy. This creates income for domestic firms and workers, increasing aggregate demand.

For the economy to be in equilibrium with stable output, total leakages must equal total injections: $S + T + M = I + G + X$. If injections exceed leakages, the economy expands; if leakages exceed injections, it contracts.

principles.principle: Total Spending Equals Total Income Equals Total Output
principles.statement: In the circular flow, every dollar spent on final goods and services becomes income for someone. This means that the total value of output produced (GDP) can be measured in three equivalent ways: as total spending on final goods and services, as total income earned from producing that output, or as total value added in production. This identity—$GDP = C + I + G + NX = Wages + Rent + Interest + Profit$—is fundamental to national income accounting.
principles.application: When analyzing the economy, remember that spending, income, and output are three sides of the same coin. A recession can be described as falling spending, falling income, or falling output—they all move together. Policy that stimulates spending (like tax cuts or government spending) will also stimulate income and output. This principle underlies the multiplier effect and Keynesian economics.
principles.example: Suppose you buy a \$1,000 laptop. That \$1,000 counts as consumption spending. It becomes revenue for the electronics firm, which pays \$600 in wages to its workers, \$200 for components, and keeps \$200 as profit. The workers, suppliers, and owners now have \$1,000 in income. That income will be spent on other goods, creating more income. The initial \$1,000 spending ripples through the economy.

image.alt: Diagram showing three equivalent measures: spending, income, and output
image.caption: Figure 2.1.8: GDP can be measured as total spending, total income, or total output. All three are equal.

principles.principle: Leakages Must Equal Injections for Macroeconomic Equilibrium
principles.statement: Leakages are withdrawals from the circular flow—savings (S), taxes (T), and imports (M). Injections are additions to the circular flow—investment (I), government spending (G), and exports (X). For the economy to be in equilibrium with stable output, total leakages must equal total injections: $S + T + M = I + G + X$. If injections exceed leakages, aggregate demand exceeds output, inventories fall, and firms increase production—the economy expands. If leakages exceed injections, demand falls short of output, inventories rise, and firms cut production—the economy contracts.
principles.application: This principle helps analyze fiscal and monetary policy. A tax cut reduces leakages (T), increasing aggregate demand. Government spending increases injections (G). Policies that encourage investment (lower interest rates) increase injections (I). Policies that affect savings or imports also affect the balance. Understanding this helps predict whether the economy will expand or contract and how policy can stabilize it.
principles.example: Suppose an economy has $S = \$100$ billion, $T = \$200$ billion, $M = \$50$ billion (total leakages = \$350 billion). Injections are $I = \$80$ billion, $G = \$180$ billion, $X = \$60$ billion (total injections = \$320 billion). Leakages exceed injections by \$30 billion, so aggregate demand is less than output. Inventories will rise, and firms will cut production. The economy will contract until leakages and injections adjust to equality (perhaps as falling income reduces savings and imports).

image.alt: Diagram showing leakages (S, T, M) leaving the flow and injections (I, G, X) entering
image.caption: Figure 2.1.9: For equilibrium, total leakages must equal total injections. If they differ, the economy adjusts.

principles.principle: The Circular Flow Shows How Fiscal Policy Affects the Economy
principles.statement: Government enters the circular flow through taxes (leakages) and spending (injections). When the government runs a deficit (spending > taxes), it injects more into the economy than it withdraws, stimulating aggregate demand. When it runs a surplus (taxes > spending), it withdraws more than it injects, restraining demand. This is why fiscal policy—changing taxes and spending—can be used to stabilize the economy. During recessions, governments often increase spending or cut taxes to boost demand. During booms, they may do the opposite to prevent overheating.
principles.application: When evaluating fiscal policy proposals, trace their effects through the circular flow. A tax cut puts more money in households' pockets, increasing consumption spending (if not saved). More spending means more revenue for firms, more income for workers, and further spending. This is the multiplier effect. Government spending directly injects money into the flow, creating income and further spending. The magnitude of the effect depends on how much of each injection is spent (rather than saved, taxed away, or spent on imports).
principles.example: During the 2008 financial crisis, the U.S. government passed the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act, which included tax cuts, increased government spending, and transfer payments. These were injections intended to offset the collapse in private investment and consumption. The circular flow model helps explain why these policies can help: they add money to the flow that would otherwise be missing, supporting income and employment.

image.alt: Circular flow diagram highlighting government sector with tax and spending flows
image.caption: Figure 2.1.10: Government affects the circular flow through taxes (leakage) and spending (injection). Deficits add net injections.

principles.principle: The Multiplier Effect Amplifies Changes in Spending
principles.statement: An initial injection of spending (or reduction in leakages) sets off a chain reaction through the circular flow. The person who receives the initial spending uses part of it to buy more goods, creating income for others, who spend part of that, and so on. This is the multiplier effect. The size of the multiplier depends on how much of each round of income is spent rather than saved, taxed, or spent on imports. The simple multiplier formula is $\frac{1}{1 - MPC}$ where MPC is the marginal propensity to consume. In the full model with taxes and imports, the multiplier is smaller.
principles.application: The multiplier helps predict the total impact of fiscal policy. If the government spends \$100 billion and the multiplier is 1.5, total GDP will increase by \$150 billion. This is why even modest stimulus can have significant effects. However, the multiplier varies with economic conditions—it's larger in recessions when resources are idle, smaller in booms when crowding out occurs. Understanding the multiplier helps policymakers design appropriate responses.
principles.example: Suppose the government spends \$100 million on highway construction. The construction workers earn income and spend 80% of it (MPC = 0.8) on consumer goods. That \$80 million becomes income for store owners and their suppliers, who spend 80% of it (\$64 million), and so on. The total increase in GDP is $\$100 \times \frac{1}{1 - 0.8} = \$100 \times 5 = \$500$ million. The initial \$100 million injection creates \$500 million in total spending.

image.alt: Diagram showing rounds of spending rippling through the circular flow
image.caption: Figure 2.1.11: The multiplier effect. An initial injection creates successive rounds of spending, amplifying the total impact.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Leakages and Injections

image.alt: Circular flow diagram with numerical values for S, T, M, I, G, X
image.caption: Figure 2.1.12: Use this diagram to calculate whether the economy is in equilibrium.

worked_examples.problem: An economy has the following flows: Savings = \$200 billion, Taxes = \$300 billion, Imports = \$100 billion, Investment = \$250 billion, Government spending = \$280 billion, Exports = \$90 billion. a) Calculate total leakages. b) Calculate total injections. c) Is the economy in equilibrium? If not, will it expand or contract? d) By how much would government spending need to change to achieve equilibrium? e) By how much would taxes need to change?

step_by_step.explanation: Leakages are savings (S), taxes (T), and imports (M). $S + T + M = \$200 + \$300 + \$100 = \$600$ billion.
Injections are investment (I), government spending (G), and exports (X). $I + G + X = \$250 + \$280 + \$90 = \$620$ billion.

Injections ($\$620$ billion) exceed leakages ($\$600$ billion) by $\$20$ billion. The economy is not in equilibrium. Since injections > leakages, aggregate demand exceeds output. Inventories will fall, and firms will increase production. The economy will expand.

step_by_step.step: Find government spending change for equilibrium
step_by_step.explanation: To achieve equilibrium, we need $S + T + M = I + G + X$. Currently $600 = 250 + G + 90$, so $600 = 340 + G$, thus $G = 260$. Current G is 280, so G would need to decrease by $\$20$ billion. This would make injections $250 + 260 + 90 = 600$, equal to leakages.

Using the equilibrium condition: $S + T + M = I + G + X$. With current S, M, I, G, X, we have $200 + T + 100 = 250 + 280 + 90$, so $300 + T = 620$, thus $T = 320$. Current T is 300, so taxes would need to increase by $\$20$ billion. This would make leakages $200 + 320 + 100 = 620$, equal to injections.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Leakages = \$600 billion. b) Injections = \$620 billion. c) No; economy will expand. d) Decrease G by \$20 billion. e) Increase T by \$20 billion.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Equilibrium requires leakages = injections. When injections exceed leakages, the economy expands; when leakages exceed injections, it contracts.

worked_examples.title: The Multiplier Effect in Action

image.alt: Table showing rounds of spending with MPC = 0.8
image.caption: Figure 2.1.13: Each round of spending is 80% of the previous round. The total is the sum of an infinite geometric series.

worked_examples.problem: The government increases spending on infrastructure by \$50 billion. Assume the marginal propensity to consume (MPC) is 0.75, and there are no taxes or imports in this simplified economy. a) Calculate the simple spending multiplier. b) Calculate the total increase in GDP. c) Show the first three rounds of spending. d) If the MPC were 0.9 instead, how would the total increase change? e) Why does the multiplier exist?

step_by_step.explanation: The simple spending multiplier is $\frac{1}{1 - MPC} = \frac{1}{1 - 0.75} = \frac{1}{0.25} = 4$.
Total increase = Initial spending × Multiplier = $\$50$ billion × 4 = $\$200$ billion.

Round 1 (initial): $\$50$ billion spent on infrastructure. This becomes income for workers and suppliers. Round 2: They spend 75% of that income = $\$50 × 0.75 = \$37.5$ billion on consumer goods. This becomes income for others. Round 3: They spend 75% of that = $\$37.5 × 0.75 = \$28.125$ billion. And so on. The total is the sum: $50 + 37.5 + 28.125 + ... = \$200$ billion.
Multiplier with MPC = 0.9 is $\frac{1}{1 - 0.9} = \frac{1}{0.1} = 10$. Total increase = $\$50 × 10 = \$500$ billion. A higher MPC means more spending in each round, so a larger multiplier.

The multiplier exists because one person's spending becomes another person's income. When that person spends part of it, it becomes someone else's income, and so on. The initial injection ripples through the economy, with each round smaller because some is saved (or in more complex models, taxed or spent on imports).

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Multiplier = 4. b) Total increase = \$200 billion. c) Round 1: \$50b, Round 2: \$37.5b, Round 3: \$28.125b. d) With MPC=0.9, total increase = \$500 billion. e) Spending becomes income, which leads to more spending.
worked_examples.concept_applied: The multiplier amplifies the impact of initial spending changes. The size depends on how much of each round of income is spent rather than saved.

worked_examples.title: Circular Flow with All Sectors

image.alt: Complete five-sector circular flow diagram with numerical values for all flows
image.caption: Figure 2.1.14: Trace the flows to answer the questions.

worked_examples.problem: Using the five-sector circular flow model, trace the following transactions and identify which flows are affected: a) A household pays $\$500$ in income taxes. b) A firm buys a new machine for $\$1$ million, borrowing the funds from a bank. c) A household buys a car manufactured in Germany for $\$30,000$. d) The government hires a new teacher at an annual salary of $\$60,000$. e) A household deposits $\$1,000$ in a savings account. For each transaction, identify: (1) Which sectors are involved, (2) Whether it's a leakage or injection (if applicable), and (3) The direction of money flow.

step_by_step.explanation: Transaction a: Household pays $\$500$ in income taxes. Sectors: Household and government. This is a leakage (taxes, T) from the circular flow. Money flows from households to government. This reduces the amount available for consumption spending.

Transaction b: Firm buys $\$1$ million machine, borrowing from bank. Sectors: Firm, financial markets, and capital goods supplier (another firm). This is an injection (investment, I). Money flows from financial markets to the firm (loan), then to the capital goods supplier (payment for machine). The supplier's income increases.

Transaction c: Household buys German car for $\$30,000$. Sectors: Household, international sector, and possibly domestic retailers. This is a leakage (imports, M). Money flows from household to international sector (through the importer). The money leaves the domestic economy.

Transaction d: Government hires teacher at $\$60,000$ salary. Sectors: Government and household. This is an injection (government spending, G). Money flows from government to household as wages. The teacher's income increases, and that income will be spent, saved, taxed, etc.

Transaction e: Household deposits $\$1,000$ in savings account. Sectors: Household and financial markets. This is a leakage (savings, S). Money flows from household to financial markets. It will later be borrowed by firms for investment (an injection).

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Household→Government, leakage (T). b) Financial markets→Firm→Firm, injection (I). c) Household→International, leakage (M). d) Government→Household, injection (G). e) Household→Financial markets, leakage (S).
worked_examples.concept_applied: Every economic transaction can be traced through the circular flow. Identifying leakages and injections helps analyze the overall impact on aggregate demand.

process_flow.description: Households own all factors of production: labor, land, capital, and entrepreneurship. They sell these resources to firms through factor markets.
process_flow.mechanism: Workers apply for jobs, landlords lease property, investors provide capital, entrepreneurs start businesses. Factor prices (wages, rent, interest, profit) are determined by supply and demand.
process_flow.result: Resources flow from households to firms. Money (income) flows from firms to households.

image.alt: Circular flow diagram highlighting factor markets and the flow of resources from households to firms
image.caption: Figure 2.1.15: Step 1 - Resources flow from households to firms through factor markets.

process_flow.description: Firms combine the resources purchased from households to produce goods and services. This production creates output that will be sold in product markets.
process_flow.mechanism: Firms organize production, seeking to produce efficiently and respond to consumer demand. The value added at each stage becomes income for resource owners.
process_flow.result: Output is created. Its value is the sum of all incomes earned in production.

image.alt: Circular flow diagram highlighting firms as producers of goods and services
image.caption: Figure 2.1.16: Step 2 - Firms use resources to produce goods and services.

process_flow.description: Households use the income they earned from supplying resources to buy goods and services from firms through product markets.
process_flow.mechanism: Consumer preferences determine what is bought. Prices adjust to balance supply and demand. Spending becomes revenue for firms.
process_flow.result: Money flows from households to firms. Goods flow from firms to households. This completes the basic circular flow.

image.alt: Circular flow diagram highlighting product markets and the flow of spending from households to firms
image.caption: Figure 2.1.17: Step 3 - Households spend income on goods and services through product markets.

process_flow.process: Government Intervenes Through Taxes and Spending
process_flow.description: Government collects taxes from households and firms (leakages) and spends on goods, services, and transfers (injections).
process_flow.mechanism: Taxes reduce disposable income and spending. Government purchases directly add to aggregate demand. Transfer payments increase household income and spending.
process_flow.result: Government can offset leakages from other sectors or add net injections to stimulate the economy.

image.alt: Circular flow diagram highlighting government sector with tax and spending flows
image.caption: Figure 2.1.18: Step 4 - Government collects taxes and injects spending into the circular flow.

process_flow.process: Financial Markets Intermediate Between Savers and Investors
process_flow.description: Households save part of their income (leakage), and these savings flow to financial markets. Firms borrow these funds for investment (injection).
process_flow.mechanism: Banks, bond markets, and stock markets channel savings to borrowers. The interest rate balances the supply of loanable funds (savings) with demand (investment).
process_flow.result: Savings are transformed into investment spending, which adds to aggregate demand and future productive capacity.

image.alt: Circular flow diagram highlighting financial markets channeling savings to investment
image.caption: Figure 2.1.19: Step 5 - Financial markets channel savings (leakage) into investment (injection).

process_flow.process: International Sector Adds Exports and Imports
process_flow.description: The rest of the world buys domestic goods (exports, injection) and sells foreign goods to domestic buyers (imports, leakage).
process_flow.mechanism: Exchange rates, foreign income, and relative prices affect export and import flows. Net exports (X - M) add to or subtract from aggregate demand.
process_flow.result: The economy is linked to global markets. Trade deficits mean net leakages abroad; trade surpluses mean net injections from abroad.

image.alt: Circular flow diagram highlighting international sector with export and import flows
image.caption: Figure 2.1.20: Step 6 - The international sector adds exports (injection) and imports (leakage).

image.alt: Complete circular flow diagram with all sectors and flows as a summary reference
image.caption: Figure 2.1.21: Complete circular flow model summary. All sectors and major flows are shown.

summary: The circular flow model is a fundamental tool in macroeconomics that shows how money, resources, and goods flow between different sectors of the economy. The simplest version includes only households and firms, connected through factor markets (where households supply resources in exchange for income) and product markets (where households spend income on goods and services produced by firms). This basic model illustrates the key identity that total spending equals total income equals total output. The model can be expanded to include government, which collects taxes (a leakage from the circular flow) and makes purchases and transfer payments (injections). Financial markets channel household savings (leakage) into business investment (injection). The international sector adds exports (injection) and imports (leakage). For the economy to be in equilibrium, total leakages (savings + taxes + imports) must equal total injections (investment + government spending + exports). When injections exceed leakages, aggregate demand exceeds output, and the economy expands; when leakages exceed injections, the economy contracts. The circular flow also helps explain the multiplier effect: an initial injection of spending creates income for others, who spend part of it, creating more income, and so on. The total impact is a multiple of the initial injection, with the multiplier depending on how much of each round of income is spent rather than saved, taxed, or spent on imports. Understanding the circular flow is essential for analyzing fiscal policy, the business cycle, and national income accounting. It provides a framework for seeing the economy as an interconnected system where changes in one sector ripple through all others.
